p: Combining the study of spatial and temporal shifts should be especially useful, as many populations are responding across both axes ( Parmesan, 2006; Fig. 1D). Furthermore, the rates and directions of response may differ on each axis. For plantâ€“pollinator interactions, the sessile nature of one partner and the mobile nature of the other means that partners are likely to respond at different rates in both space and time, so it is important to study the effects of changes in both dimensions. In addition, spatial transplants often affect phenology due to altered abiotic conditions (e.g., Anderson and Gezon, 2015), and the timing of life history events may shape the spatial niches and distributions of species ( Chuine and Beaubien, 2001). Thus, it is important to explicitly consider shifts along one axis resulting from shifts along the other.
